newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RUGBY LEAGUE-AUSTRALIANS BRACE THEMSELVES FOR GRAND FINAL FRENZY.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY LEAGUE-AUSTRALIANS BRACE THEMSELVES FOR GRAND FINAL FRENZY.

text.p: Australians were bracing
themselves on Friday for their biggest sporting weekend of the
year featuring the annual rugby league and Australian Rules
football grand finals, events which have triggered virtual
sporting civil wars.
The action kicks off in Melbourne on Saturday with the
Aussie Rules grand final between North Melbourne and the Sydney
Swans.
North Melbourne represent the 100-year-old, uniquely
Australian game's heartland in the southern state of Victoria,
while the Swans are 15-year-old newcomers and the only team from
Victoria's neighbours New South Wales.
Sunday sees the final match of a tumultuous year for the
Australian Rugby League, with ageing heavyweights St George
pitted against the heavily-favoured but widely disliked Manly.
St George, a traditional powerhouse in the 88-year history
of the Australian Rugby League (ARL), reached the grand final
after being rated 100-1 outsiders at the start of the season.
The old working-class club from Sydney's southern suburbs,
is in the Guinness Book of World Records for its 11 consecutive
titles in the 1950s and 60s, the only team to have achieved the
feat in any football code.
But St George was almost forced to merge with another inner
city club early this year because of financial problems.
It then lost two coaches and several key players in the
fallout of the bitter battle for control of the game between the
ARL and media tycoon Rupert Murdoch's banned rebel Super League.
Manly, a rich club from Sydney's exclusive northern beaches,
is the team much of Sydney loves to hate.
Manly's number one fan, author Tom Keneally, reportedly told
incoming New South Wales state police commissioner, Englishman
Peter Ryan, that he should support Manly in order to assimilate
into Sydney culture.
Others warned Ryan his job trying to clean up corruption in
the state force would be even more difficult with the massive
plunge in popularity support of Manly would bring.
Politicians have been quick to jump on the sporting
bandwagon, with the state premiers of New South Wales and
Victoria indulging in a week of sniping over the match.
Victorians have accused their northern neighbours of trying
to usurp their game while Sydney supporters say Victorians are
using dirty tricks to avoid being beaten at their own game.
Australia Prime Minister John Howard, whose electorate is in
Sydney, on Friday came out in support of St George and the
Sydney Swans, who both wear red and white playing strips.
"I'm going for a red and white double...St George by four or
five, Sydney by 10," Howard told business leaders at a lunch in
Melbourne.
